text: Panoramic shot of western prairie. In the far distance WE SEE a speck of activity on the horizon.

text: We HEAR the faint SOUNDS of clanking and voices. As CAMER GETS CLOSER we begin to make out shapes of men hard at wo CAMERA CONTINUES TO MOVE IN. Through the heat shimmer we are now able to distinguish t this is a railroad work gang made up of Blacks, Chinese a Irish immigrant laborers. They are hard at work laying track westward, under the watchful gaze of cruel overseer
the assistant foreman, walks into frame. He is obviously dissatisfied. He is flanked by two cruel overseers. He takes out a pocket watch, glances at it and puts it back.
C'mon boys. The way you're lolly- gagging around here with them shovels you'd think it was 120 degrees. Couldn't be more than 114. Ha, ha, ha. A Chinese man falls over from the heat.
(continuing) — Dock that chink a day's pay for napping on the job.
Right, Lyle.
Now c'mon boys, where's your spirit? When you were slaves you sang like birds. How about a good old nigger work song.  2.

They are sweating profusely, They look at each other. Our hero, BLACK BART, shuffles forward. He is a handsome wiry black man in his late 20's. His appearance suggests that he is somewhat ahead of his time. He takes off his hat, mops his brow in good old darkie fashion and then turns t his fellow workers and nods. They hum a chord.
(segues into up-tempo, Sinatra-style rendition of:)

Looking at each other in amazement.
Hold it! Hold it! What the hell is that shit! I meant a song. Something like "Swing Low Sweet Chariot". A song!
and his co-workers, They pretend to be puzzled. cur TO:

"De Camptown Ladies Sing Dis Song, Doo-Dah, Doo-Dah. De Camptown Race Track Five Miles Long, All The Doo- Dah Day. All The Doo-Dah Night, ALL The Doo-Dah Day",

The man is TAGGART, the burly heartless, foreman. Taggart rides over and strikes Lyle on the head with a swagger stick.
What in the wide, wide world of sports is going on here? TI hired you to get some track laid, not to jump around like a bunch of Kansas City faggots.
Sorry, Mr. Taggart...got caught up.
Listen, shithead. Surveyor says there might be some quicksand up ahead.
Okay, 1'11 send down a team of horses to test the ground.
(smashes him on head with swagger stick) Horses: Are you crazy? We can't afford to lose horses. Send two niggras.
You and you. Lyle points to Bart and CHARLIE, another black worker.

But, sir, he specifically asked for two niggras. To tell a family secret, wy grandmother was Dutch. Are you familiar with Holland? Well, you know where Antwerp cuts off Rotterdam? Well, right there we ran this little after hours windmill... (apical exploding Get on that handear and take it down to the end of the line. Bart and Charlie walking to the handcar.
I had no idea your Grandmama was Dutch. (CONTINUED)
8 (Cont.)
Well, Grandfather said she was always hanging around with a lot of dykes. They crack up and slap each other off. They hop on the handcar and start pumping their way down the track. cur TO:
on the handcar moving along the track.
pumping. Suddenly they come to a dead stop. They stare at each other and slowly they begin to sink out of the frame. We HEAR a strange gurgling noise.
4m I wrong or is the world rising?
I don't know but whatever it is, I hate it.
Lh. MASTER SHOT BART AND CHARLIE waist deep in quicksand.

Hey Charlie, let me ask you something. Now don't be too hasty with your answer. Put some thought to it. What is it that's not exactly water and it ain't exactly earth and when it sucks you under it squeezes the last shred of breath out of your lungs till you die? Bart and Charlie look at each other.
(shouting)
12. TAGCART AND LYLE caro ride into the scene, a look of disgust on their faces. Taggart climbs down off his horse and throws his hat down.
Quicksand. Shit. Now we're in trouble.
in quicksand up to their necks.

Now let's see here, we can't go straight ahead and we can't swing vight because of this ravine. We're gonna have to turn north... He turns around toward the direction of Bart and Charlie.

(continuing) «..to Rock Ridge. (to Bart & Charlie) Would you folks hold it down just aminute. We are trying to get some work done here. We can't hear our- selves think with all that "help" going on. Now let's see... cUuT TO:
(softer) Help. Help. Two human beings dying. <ConTINUED)  7. 15 (Cont.) CHARLIE; Two brothers heading for the basement. CUT TO;
Holy cow! Hurry, Lyle, get a rope. Lyle gets rope from saddle - twirls loop over his head vigorously,
(continuing; impressed with this fancy twirling) Hey, Lyle, can you still do that fancy thing with the rope?
I don't know. I'll try. Lyle does fancy rope act - jumps through loop and other elaborate rope tricks. oot To.
staring at each other in disbelief. CUT TO;

Lyle is tying end of rope to back of wagon.
Hurry up. There's $400 worth of handear sinking there. curt TO:

Handear! Hey you stupid sonova- bitch, what about us? Taggart walks over to edge of quicksand where Bart is straining to reach an overhanging branch. Taggart places his boot heel on Bart's forehead. TAGGART; Now that's the kind of attitude that holds you people back. Maybe if you had a little respect for your betters you could make your way up in this world.
Up. That's what we want - up! (CONTINUED)

Lemme get back to you on that... Lyle. Taggart walks away. In a last desperate effort, Bart mana to grab on to the handcar. Charlie grabs Bart's legs and two are pulled out together with the handear. They lie th trying to catch their breath.
(to the exhausted Bart and Charlie) Okay boys, the break is over. Let's not lie around taking sun baths. Won't do you much good anyway. Taggart and Lyle are convulsed by Taggart's dry wit.

(continuing) Here, put this shovel to some good use. He drops shovel on the ground next to Bart and walks back toward Lyle. Bart grabs shovel, stands up and takes vicio practice swings with it. Charlie looks at Bart.
Don't do it baby.
I have to! Bart starts walking toward Taggart and Lyle.
We're in a heap of trouble and we're going to need a lot of extra supplies. Write this down. Lyle pulls out paper and pencil.
(continuing) Now wire the main office in Topeka and tell them that I... (CONTINUED)

(continuing) -..said OW! He drops like a stone.
(does not notice; continues writing) 'Wire main office and tell them I said OW!' Got it, curt TO:

Rider on horseback pulls up to Capital building steps. A little to the right of him we SEE a stagecoach in the process of being held up. Bandits with black bandanas over their faces point guns at men and women who stand with their arms raised. Rider pays no attention to scene. He rushes up steps into building.
Sign on frosted glass.

of map on wall. Map depicts the progress of the railroad construction. Finger enters FRAME and points to end of red line on map. SLOW ZOOM BACK TO REVEAL Taggart standing in front of map, pointing. His head is swathed in bandages. His hat rests way atop bandages.
(pointing) And right here, Mr. Lamarr, is where we ran into the quicksand. (CONTINUED )
25 (Cont.) He touches forehead tenderly. He is still‘obviously in gr pain.
He studies map intently.
Quicksand. Quicksand...splendid.
So now the railroad's gotta go through Rock Ridge.
(carefully digesting the news) Rock Ridge. Rock Ridge...splendid.
Yes, sir...yes, sir. Rock Ridge... Rock Ridge.
Be still, Taggart. My mind is aglow with whirling transient nodes of thought careening through a cosmic vapor of invention. There is a long pause.
Ditto.
Shut up!
Yes, sir.
A plan, a plan, I need a plan. He gets up and paces behind his desk. Suddenly there is a fearful CRASH eminating from just outside of Lamarr's window.  27. 28. 28A. 28B. 28C. 12.

Oh, yes, the Dr. Gillespie killings. Do your best. Lamarr pulls down the shade. There is an incredible CRASH outside as the man in the wheelchair goes through the tra door.
Now where were we...oh, yes. Rock Ridge. When that railroad comes through Rock Ridge, the property there will be worth millions and I want it. I want that land so badly I can taste it.
takes Lamarr's words literally. He tries to imagine eatin dirt. He doesn't like it.
Mv . — LAMARR:
Yes, sir.
Unfortunately there is one thing that stands between me and that property, and that's the rightful owners. There must be a way of scaring them out.*
What about killing the first born male child in each household,
No, that's been done to death.
I don't think we have anything to worty about. We can work up a number six on them. (CONTINUED)
Number six? I don't think I'm familiar with that one.
That's just where we ride into town at dawn thrashing everything that moves to within an inch of its life...except the women folk, of course.
Oh, you spare the women?
Oh no, we rape the shit out of them at the number six dance that follows.
It sounds grotesque but enter- taining...just might work. (Lamarr notices Taggart's bandages for the first time) Why Taggart, you've been hurt.
Yes, sir. This uppity niggra hit me with a shovel and f would appreciate it if you could find it in your heart to hang him. He's locked up downstairs.

Consider it done. Lamarr raises window shade. Through window WE SEE a rider and horse being led up to the gallows. Boris places one noose around the rider's neck and another noose around th horse's neck.

(putting noose around horse's neck) I couldn't pothibly thneak him in until Monday, thir. We're J bocked tholid.  30. 31. 32 15.
Monday. Splendid. Lamarr pulls down shade.
Much obliged. And don't you worry, Mr, Lamarr...we'll make Rock Ridge sorry it was ever born.
Splendid! We HEAR a big CRASH from outside as horse and rider go plummeting through the trap door.
Thorry. (v.0.)

head_text.subj: ROCK RIDGE WHERE PEOPLE LIVED IN
SHOT OF MAIN STREET ROCK RIDGE

text: People are walking up and down street. A little boy is rolling a hoop. A buckboard with happy family drives by. People pass and tip their hats in greeting.

head_text.subj: THEY NEVER HAD NO KIND OF TROUBLE
THERE WAS NO HINT OF MISERY.

text: CAMERA TRACKS SHOTS OF MERCHANTS waving happily from door to passers-by.
(v.0.) : THE TOWN SALOON WAS ALWAYS LIVELY. Men at bar, they are all drinking and chatting politely. small herd of cattle moves through the saloon. cuoriis : (v.0.) BUT NEVER NASTY OR OBSCENE.
A big dirty animal of a man. He cleans shot glasses by sp ting into them and wiping them with his filthy apron..

head_text.subj: BEHIND THE BAR STOOD ANAL JOHNSON
HE ALWAYS KEPT THINGS NICE AND CLEAN
THEN ALL AT ONCE THE TROUBLE STARTED.

text: Suddenly SHOTS ring out and the saloon windows shatter. Everyone ducks for cover. cuT TO: EXT. ROCK RIDGE ‘DAY

head_text.subj: A PACK OF MURDERERS AND THIEVES
LIKE SWARMS OF LOCUST THEY DESCENDED
THEIR AIM TO MAKE THE TOWN FOLK

Band of desperados led by Taggart and Lyle swoop into town. They FIRE wildly in the air. People scatter and horses rear in fright. They ride through the center of town performing various frontier cruelties: overturning buckboards, riding by and whomping citizens over the head.
He comes out of his office,

(continuing; as he is oing down. Oh, that's the meaning.

Hurry boys, it's a fire sale. Ha, ha, ha.

What is this, anyhow,..your flat or your e-namel?

head_text.subj: . OUR. TOWN IS TURNING INTO SHIT.

text: Revised 2/22/73 CUT TO;
Standing at pulpit.
Be seated. People sit.

I don" t have to tell you good folks what's been happening to our beloved little town. Sheriff murdered, crops burned, stores ransacked, people stampeded and cattle raped. The time has come to act and act fast. I'm leaving. Reverend starts off platform. Townsfolk ad lib.
a grizzled little grub-staker in shredded, but stylish, buckskins. He chaws tobacco and spits great globs of brownish gook as verbal punctuation.
Hol' on. Consarnit, goll-darnit. I'll be a horn-swaggeled bush- whackin' side-windin' saddle horn .».Ravvid, ravvid, ravvid... : (the rest of his dialogue is completely incomprehensible)
There is total silence in the church as everyone carefull digests what has just been said. Gabby sits.  21. Revised 2/22/73
He rises slowly and majestically and faces the crowd.

Now how can we argue with that. LI think we are all indebted to Gabby Johnson here for clearly stating what had to be said, And I'm glad the children were here today to hear that speech, Not only was it authentic frontier gibberish.,,but it expressed a courage that is little seen in this day and age. I mean, what are we made of? Our fathers came across the prairie, fought Indians, fought drought, fought locusts, fought Dix. Remember when Richard Dix came in here and tried to take the town away? We didn't give up then and by gum we're not giving up now. Olson Johnson sits.
(he rises) Olson Johnson is right. What kind of people are we anyhow? I say we stay and fight it out.
(rising) Dr. Samuel Johnson's right about Olson Johnson's being right. And I'm not giving up my ice cream parlor that I built with these two hands for nothing or nobody.
Howard Johnson is right.
Thank you, Van.

Well, if we're gonna stay, and I think it's a big mistake, we're gonna have to have us a sheriff. Who's it gonna be?  44D (Cont.) Pause. 22. Revised 2/22/73 REV. JOHNSON: (Cont.) All right, nominations for the office of Sheriff Johnson are now in order.
I say we nominate Olson.
Gentlemen, I am honored. But I must decline on the grounds of I won't do it. LI nominate Van Johnson,
I am not unaware of the prestige and the honor of the office of Sheriff. I am also not unaware of the death that frequently accompanies the job. I am thereby forced by good sense and fear to decline.

This town can't survive without a sheriff to keep the peace. Now, who's it gonna be? Everyone shuffles in their seats uneasily. A little boy (Henry) breaks away from his mother, jumps into aisle and makes speech.
I want to be the sheriff. I can do it. TI can do it. Please make me the sheriff. Please make me the sheriff. cUT TO:
seriously considering it. Congregation ad lib.
Why don't we wire the Governor to send us a sheriff. Why should we get our own men killed? (CONTINUED)
Howard Johnson is absolutely right. We'll wire the Governor.
Let us pray for the deliverance of our new sheriff. The congregation will rise. They all rise.
(continuing) I will now read from the books of Matthew, Mark, Luke and... Shattering of glass as some lighted dynamite comes through window, ?
(continuing) DUCK. There is a huge explosion.
curt TO:

CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal smoke-filled room. GOVERNOR WILLIAM J, LE PETOMANE is at one end of table flanked by his voluptuous, crimson-haired secretary, Miss Stein, and Hedley Lamarr. Governor Le Petomane is a silver-haire silver-tongued moron. Other men at table are state officials, politicians, ward heelers, etc. Lamarr shoves a paper in front of Le Petomane.
Sign this, Governor, (CONTINUED)
46A (Cont.)
What is it?
Under the provisions of this bill, the Cheyenne nation would give us 200,000 square acres of their land which we have deemed unsafe for their use at this time.
Oh, wonderful. What are we giving them in return?
& box of these. Lamarr takes out hi-1li paddle and displays it.
Seems like a fair exchange. (lowers his voice) You think you could save one of . those beauties for me? Woo-Woo.
Of course, sir. If you'll just sign here. Lamarr then takes Le Petomane's right hand and guides it through the signature. A small herd of cattle passes through his office,
Work, work, work. What's next?
Just one more bill for you to sign, sir.
What is it?
This is the bill that will convert the state hospital for the insane into the William J. Le Petomane Memorial Gambling Casino for the insane. (CONTINUED)
(rising to his feet) This bill will be a giant step forward in the treatment of the insane gambler.
Beautifully put. No wonder they call you the silver-tongued orator.
(sitting down) Thank you, Heddy.
It's not Heddy, Governor... Hedley, Hedley Lamarr.
(friendly aside) What are you worried about? This is 1874... you can sue her.
Just sign here.
(as his hand is being pushed along paper) Watch the n's. Watch the n's. Cross the T, cross the T... if you don't cross the T it looks like a big L and ya get Le Pelomane, Is that it?
Just this urgent telegram from Rock Ridge that came in last Friday.
Read it... read it. (under his breath) You wild bitch.
(reading telegram) "Sheriff murdered. Church meeting bombed, reign of terror must cease, send new sheriff immediately", (CONTINUED)
46A (Cont.2) There is 26.

(rising to his feet) Hrumph, Hrumph... murdering sheriffs, bombing churches, innocent women and children blown up. Normally I wouldn't give a damn, but this is an election year and we've got to protect our phoney, baloney jobs. general hubbub at the conference table. (rising) Gentlemen, please rest your sphincters. As. Attorney General, I assure you a suitable sheriff will be found to restore the peace in Rock Ridge. Meeting adjourned. Excuse me, Governor, I didn't mean to overstep my bounds. You say that.
What?
Meeting is adjourned. Lamarr leaves.
Oh, it is.
No, Governor. You say that.
What?
Never mind.

Good man but he's nervous. Tall people are very nervous. Too far from the earth. Give me one of those things, will ya sweetheart. Miss Stein hands him a hi-li paddle. Does four swipes at the ball. Misses every time, (CONTINUED)
These are defective. Throws it back into the box and EXITS, cUT TO:
Lamarr is pacing up and down.

A sheriff, a sheriff. But law and order is the last thing I want. (he stops and smiles) Perhaps I can turn this to my ad- vantage. If I can find a sheriff who so offends the citizens of Rock Ridge that his very appearance would drive them out of town. But where would I find such a man? We HEAR the noises of a commotion. Lamarr goes to window and looks down.
Bart is being led to the front of a long line of men waiting to be hanged.
Hey, what's goin' on, I'm next. Men ad lib.
(to guard) Perhaps we better wait. After all they were here before me.
48 (Cont.) Guard pushes Bart up steps. Bart mounts steps to scaffold Boris places noose around his neck. BORIS; Would you care for a blindfold or an after dinner mint?
No, thank you. Do you have any- thing in the way of a reprieve? o BORIS: Thorry.

(reading from state document) In accordance with the ordinance signed by John Mordinance, the prisoner is to be hanged by his neck to pay for sub-ordinance. If the prisoner has no last words, we'll proceed with the hanging. Hang him. Boris reaches for lever.
Wait, wait, Last words, last words. I£ you don't mind, I'd like a brief chat with my maker before I meet him in person.
Of course. Bart whips off his hat.
Let us bow our heads in prayer. Oh Lord, I don't know why I'm being hung but it really doesn't matter. He slowly slips noose from around his neck.

(continuing) Because sooner or later all who walk upright must take the long nap. He surreptitiously edges his way down the steps and quiet makes his way through the courtyard. No one sees him because all heads are bowed in prayer. (CONTINUED)

(continuing) Yea verily, the leaves that are green in the spring must soonith or ‘later turnith brownith in the fallith. It is with love, not hatred, that I make my way toward the pearly gates of everlasting freedom. He is almost out of the courtyard when suddenly, INTO THE FRAME, pressed against his head is the long silver barrel of a 6-shooter. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal it ia held by Hedley Lamarr.
Beautifully put. I'd like a word with you - do you have a moment?
OMITTED , . ‘
Lamarr enters with arm around Bart. Bart is wearing a sheriff's badge. He impassively surveys the scene.
(v.o.) Governor. The drapes stop moving. Governor Le Petomane's head pops out from behind the drapes. (CONTINUED)
Yes.
Official business, sir.
Be with you in a minute.
(v.0.; behind drapes). What is it, Bill?
(v.o.; head ducks back behind drapes) Just a trifle, my dear. Throw a robe on...the floor is dirty. I'11 be back in a minute. Governor emerges from behind drapes tucking in his shirt tails.
Oh, hello. Sorry to be tardy. I was just looking out the wall. What can I do for you, Hedley.
Governor, as per your instructions, I'd like you to meet the new sheriff of Rock Ridge.
(to Bart) I'm pleased to mee... (to Lamarr) Lamarr, have you gone berserk? This man's a nigger. (to Bart) No offense, son.
Have a seat, sheriff, while we straighten this little matter out. Bart goes to corner of room and sits. (CONTINUED)

Lamarr, I have never questioned your judgment before but haven't you taken a giant leap away from your own good senses? You can't make a nigger (to Bart) no offense... (to Lamarr) the new sheriff of Rock Ridge.
Now don't fly off the handle, Governor. I am about to make you an historic figure, maybe get you a cabinet post.
Cabinet post? Cabinet post?
The first man to ever appoint a black sheriff. Just think of it, Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln, Le Petomane.
But it won't work. They'll never accept him. They'll kill that nigger (to Bart) no offense (to Lamarr) dead in one day.
One day is all we need for your fame to be secure in the annals of Western history. And that will surely secure you the nomination for, dare I say, the Presidency? go LE PETOMANE: Dare, dare.
The Presidency. Governor strides over to Bart. (CONTINUED)
(humming "Hail To The Chief") Good luck nigger, no offense. And I hope that you bring glory, brief as it may be, to this hallow state.
(v.o.) Bill are you coming back?
(deftly stepping out of his trousers Is that it Heddey, I'm terribly busy.
Of course, of course, affairs of state.
Very, very funny. You know I can still have you fired. Can I fire you?
No, you can't, Governor.
All right, good luck. Governor Le Petomane goes behind the drapes.

running up street holding telegram.

What'd he say?
The sheriff is near. Townspeople start to cheer.
(AD LIB)
The sheriff is near. The sheriff is near.
No, no, the sheriff is a ni-- BELL GONGS drown out last part of nigger.

Cheering reaches pandemonium stage. Bart is now only fifty.feet away but still cannot be seen clearly because of the dust. The dust clears. Townspeople see Bart for the first time. As his horse slowly trots down the main street, the music peters out in ragged dissonance.
placing cap over mouthpiece.
They are frozen in a tableau of stupefaction. cur TO:
who has not seen Bart enter. His eyes are glued to his paper as he reads his speech.
The town of Rock Ridge is happy to extend a laurel and hearty welcome to its new... (he sees Bart) nigger.

He tips his hat in acknowledgement. Bart rides to center of town and gets off his horse. Nobody moves. Their eyes follow him as he starts climbing stairs of speaker's platform. He walks up slow and steady.

1, Gabby Johnson, his tongue, the only thing on his face not frozen in horror, “dangtes “Exom his mouth, He shakes his head and says "Ravvid, ravvid, rav..v... it 2. A woman holding her hands over her little girl's eyes. 3. Olson Johnson slowly, silently mouthing the word, "Wow
on speaker's platform. He reaches inside his belt.
Excuse me, while I whip this out. A piercing SCREAM rends the air.  77. 78.
curt TO:
screaming and fainting.
He whips out rolled up proclamation from inside his gun belt. Collective gasp of relief issues from the crowd. Bart unrolls proclamation and begins reading.
By the power vested in me...
pull out their guns and begin loading them.
(continuing) .-.by the Honorable William J. Le Petomane,,,
Men who continue to load and cock six shooters, rifles an shotguns. CUT BACK TO;
He raises his eyebrows, indicating he is growing rapidly aware of the impending danger.
(continuing; quickening pace of his speech) ...-I hereby assume the duties of the office of sheriff in and for the township of Rock Ridge. (CONTINUED)
82 (Cont.) 83. 84. Reverend Johnson, who has been standing next to Bart, leaps forward and raises his arms. He is holding a Bible.

Gentlemen, Gentlemen, Let's not allow anger to rule the day. As your spiritual leader I implore you to pay heed to this good book and what it has to say. Especially those instructions handed down to us by Abraham, Isaac and Solomon... A LOUD SHOTGUN BLAST blows a hole through the center of the Bible.

(continuing) Unfortunately, those instructions are now somewhere over Omaha. (to Bart) Son, you're on your om. I must take shelter so as to preach another day. He crouches down into a Little ball at the base of the platforn. CUT To: TOWNS PEOPLE. They are all aiming their guns at Bart.
He is clearly frightened. He closes his eyes tightly as if to squeeze out a thought.
(softly; to himself) Tt might work. Bart whips out his gun and presses it to his own neck.
(continuing) Hold it, Next man makes a move, the nigger gets it. in a different voice as a cringing, whining plantation darkie) (CONTINUED)
39 84 (Cont.) 85. 86. 87. BART: (Cont.) He means it. He means it. He'll do it. I know him.
(continuing) You bet your ass I'll do it.
They are bewildered.
Hold on men. He's not bluffing. He'll kill ‘im sure as shooting.
Now throw your guns down. Gentle like, no tricks.
(other voice) Please, please don't shoot. Throw down your guns. He means it. He means it.

Listen to him, men. He's just crazy enough to do it. Men throw down guns. Bart backs down street still keeping tightly pressed against his own neck, He spots man Van Jotinson) on.roof raising rifle. ,
(to Van) * Drop it or I swear I'll blow this nigger's head all over the street, (CONTINUED)
ho, 87 (Cont.)
(other voice) Oh, Lordie, Lordie, he's desperate. Do what he says,
Drop it, Van. .He's*serious.. , cuUT TO:
on roof.
(frustrated) Aw, shoot. Van drops rifle from roof and it clatters to ground.
He slowly continues backing down street toward jail house
(tearfully) Isn't anybody gonna help that poor man?
Hush, Harriet, that's a sure way to get him killed,
He is only a few feet away from the jail house. (CONTINUED)
Easy now, just a few feet more. Bart suddenly makes a run for it but quickly stops him- self with a shot just past his head. The town gasps.
That was just a warning. The next time he tries it he gets it right between the eyes.

Go along with him, son. There'll be another time. Bart eases himself, backwards very slowly, until he reaches the jail house door, other hand behind him, opening door. The last thing we see is his anguished expression as he pushes himself inside and SLAMS DOOR. CUT TO;
Bart stands with his back against the door. He heaves a great sigh of relief.
Made it. You are so talented. He throws his arms around himself in a big hug.
(continuing) I love you.
(other voice) Not here.
CAMERA PANS along piles of railroad construction material Set off from the rest of the campsite by a barbed wire fence, is Taggart's headquarters. Sign on fence reads:

head_text.subj: KNOCK ON BARBED WIRE BEFORE ENTERING

text: (CONTINUED)
he. 93 (Cont.) 94. Through the fence WE SEE a campfire, men seated around it cuT TO:

Five of Taggart's henchmen are seated around the campfire No one talks. They are busy, noisely scraping the last of their beans off tin plates. The only SOUND WE HEAR is a vulgar symphony of eating, grunting, belching and farti Taggart steps out of his tent and approaches the campfire
Got word there's a new sheriff in town. Who wants to kill him? ALL henchmen raise their hands like eager children in sch One man pulls another man's hand down. A squabble begins.
Mr. Taggart, Mr. Taggart, sir... I believe I have a ee-nuque idea.
Ee-nuque? Don't you mean unique?
That's probably what I mean.
What is it?
What's what?
Your ee-nuque idea.
Oh. Why don't we give him to Mongo. Mongo'd sure see to his ass,
(v.o.; AD LIB) Mongo. Great idea. Have a heart Taggart. Hey, Mongo will eat him for breakfast. They all laugh. (CONTINUED)
94 (Cont.)
What do you say, Mongo?

head_text.subj: CAMERA DRIFTS AROUND OTHER SIDE OF CAMPFIRE

text: He's a huge mountain of a man. Straddled between his legs is a mammoth black cauldron of bubbling beans. He uses a fireplace shovel to get the beans into his gaping yaw of a mouth. taggart walks over io him.
Well, Mongo, how would you Like to mutilate the new sheriff? Mongo smiles and issues forth a nearly human noise.

Good boy. Mongo reaches into his boot and pulls out a huge cigar, bites end off and spits it across campfire. Mongo then sticks his entire face into the raging campfire to light his cigar, As he comes back out of the campfire we see the upper half of him quietly, smoldering.
How you want sheriff killed? A11 at once, or little pieces?
Use your own warped judgment.

head_text.subj: INT. SHERIFF'S OFFICE JAIL HOUSE NIGHT

text: CLOSEUP of fine tipped artist's paint brush being dipped into small can of white paint. The brush comes out. We follow it over to a jockey ashtray whose black face is no being painted white. CAMERA PULLS BACK to show Bart putti the finishing touches on the face. (CONTINUED)

There. That's better, Bart puts paint down on desk and picks up a sheaf of "Wanted" posters. He walks over to the bulletin board and begins tacking them up. The first three are of mean looking white outlaws. The fourth handbill is of a black man. Bart studies it, crumples it up and throws it in the wastebasket.
(TO CAMERA)
He's got enough trouble without a bunch of honkies chasing his ass all over Mexico. We HEAR a tremendous CRASH coming from one of the jail ce
The drunk in #2 must be up. He walks over to the row of cells. Stops at #2.
We SEE a man dangling upside down, his heels caught in th rail of the upper bunk,
Now, that's what you call hung over. (to prisoner) Are we awake?
We're not sure, Are we black?
Yes. We are.
Then we're awake... And we're puzzled. I better straighten myself out. (CONTINUED)
98 (Cont.) Jim struggles to right himself.
Need any help?
All I can get. Bart unlocks cell door and helps Jim to his feet.
Thank you.
Maybe you'd better have something to eat.
No, thanks, Food makes me sick. Jim reaches over and takes a bottle from the upper bunk, uncorks it and drinks it clean.
Ahhhhhh.
Hey, if a man drinks like that and he don't eat, he's gonna die.
When? Bart studies him carefully. CAMERA MOVES INTO Jim's face. Jim is a 40'ish, over-the-hill, leather-faced, gunfighter with the saddest eyes God ever *made.
What's your name?
(holding fingers to his head) Jim. But most people call me Jim.
Okay, Jim. Since you're my guest and I'm your host what do you like to do? What are your pleasures?
I dunno, screw...play chess. (CONTINUED)
ke. 98 (Cont.1)
Let's play chess. cut TO:
A tumultous town meeting is in progress. The place is bedlam. Reverend Johnson, at the pulpit, raps his gavel sharply.
Order! Order!
Nietzche says "Qut of chaos comes order."
Oh, blow it out your ass, Howard,

Now everyone be quiet whilst we listen to Harriet Van Johnson, our esteemed schoolmarm; as she reads a telegram that she herself has composed to the Governor, expressing our feelings about the new sheriff.
Shyly rising to her feet.
To the Honorable William J. Le Petomane, Governor.
(v.o0.) Louder. We can't hear you. Speak up.
Forgive me. I'm not used to public a oeeeen she s eaks a little Touder) (CONTINUED)

100 (Cont.) ur. HARRIET VAN JOHNSON: (Cont. ) We, the white God-fearing citizens of Rock Ridge wish to express our extreme displeasure with your choice of sheriff. Please remove him immediately. The fact that you have sent him here just goes to prove that you are the leading asshole in the state. People start cheering and applauding. They scatter as a small herd of cattle moves through the church.
Bart and Jim are playing chess,
You mean they just rode in here, busted up the town, killed the sheriff£...for no reason?
No reason I know of. Nothing here worth takirg.
Got to be a reason. (makes chess move) I'll find out.
(of£f£-handedly) I wouldn't worry about that. You'll probably be dead before you get the answer. But I would worry about that move you just made.
Oh dear, you're right. I've just put my queen in jeopardy.
Go on, take it back.
No, I did it and I'll have to take the consequences. I'm not a baby. (he grabs his nose and begins sucking his thumb) (CONTINUED)
Th 101 (Cont.)
All right, you lose your queen. (he takes queen)
(making move with flourish) Checkmate.
(amazed)
(spelling it out) CHECKMATE,. Checkmate!
You devious son-of-a-bitch.

Forgive me. I know this is petty but I've got to do it. (he leaps to his feet and does a little dance of victory) I won. You lost. I'm great. You stink. Another game, chump? Jim shakes his head, pulls out 1/2 bottle of whiskey and finishes it. BART: . Hey, man, why do you do that to yourself?
Do you really want to know?
Yeah, I'm seriously considering writing you up for the Reader's Digest as the most unforgettable drunk I have ever known.
Well, once upon a time they used to call me the Waco Kid, (CONTINUED)
uo.
(jumping to his feet) Yeah, and they used to call me The Ritz Brothers. The Waco Kid. Man, he had the fastest hands in the West.
(indignantly) In the world.
If you're the Kid, show me something.
Well, maybe years ago I could've shown you something...but today... (lifts his hands; they tremble)
I knew you were no Waco Kid. You were just pullin' my lariat.
All right. All right. See that king? Now put your hands on both sides of it. (Bart does so) When I go for the king, you try to grab it first.
Man, that's no contest. You're a mile away.
Never mind. When I say "go" you just try to grab it. Ready?
Go!
He clasps his hands over the king and smiles victoriously He opens his palms and looks. inside. His expression changes to surprise.
(he takes king from under his hat} Looking for this?
Well, raise my rent. You are the Kid,

Was. Yeah was. I was the Kid. Every prairie rat who could draw a gun from Yuma to Laredo had to ride into town to try out the Kid, I must have killed more men than Napoleon at Moscow. Yeah, it got pretty gritty. I'd hear the word "draw" in my sleep, And then one day, walking down the street, I heard a voice behind me say "Reach for it, Mister," I spun around and there I am face-to-face with a six year old kid.. Well, I threw my guns down and walked away. Little bastard shot me in the ass, I limped over to the saloon, crawled inside a whiskey bottle and been there ever since. (CONTINUED)
105 (Cont.) 106. 107. Bart picks up bottle.
Have a drink. Jim takes bottle, laughs, takes a slug.
But that's ancient history. What's your story? What's a dazzling ur- banite like you doing put here?
Well, back in '56 my folks and I were part of this long wagon train moving west. Bart imitates a harp in traditional movie flashback manner, BART; Doong, Doong, Doong, Doong.
WE SEE line of Conestoga wagons heading West.

(v.o.) Well, not exactly part of it. Several hundred yards to the rear of the main body of covered wagons, eating dust all the way, WE SEE a little wagon that is obviously less well to do than the others.
Driving the wagon is a black man. Seated next to him is his wife and his ten year old son (young Bart).
(v.o.) You might say we were bringing up the rear, when suddenly, from out of the West, came the entire Sioux nation. And let me tell you, they were open for business. . (CONTINUED)

107 (Cont.) 108. 109. 110. 111. WE SEE (STOCK FOOTAGE) outlined against the horizon, a long line of Indians. They swoop down on the wagon train whooping and yelling God knows what. The wagons begin to form a classic western circle.
(v.0.) Naturally, they didn't let us travel in their circle. So, we made our own.
turning in little circles.
attacking. In a short time they reduce the wagon train to smoldering ashes. (END STOCK FOOTAGE.)
It is encircled by Indians. Bart and his parents stare at them in terror.
They stare back in wonder.
(v.0.) You might say they were a little confused by the color of our skin. Then, in rode the big chief.  112. 113. 53. . cuT TO:
in full-feathered regalia. He stares for a long time at Bart and his family.
(to brave in half Indian, half Yiddish) Ahm...ma.,.ma...yah...va... shvartzes? The Chief is faced with a dilemma. He thinks hard and finally comes to a decision.
Manoma...Moma...Coma... (he raises his arms to the sky) La Zehn Azoi....Luzem gayen. Abi gezunt. Chief wheels his horse and rides off, Braves follow.
And the rest is history. (he looks up) Impressed? We HEAR the SOUND of snoring. Jim is fast asleep.

(shakes his head) Yeah, I like to keep my audience riveted, Bart goes over to Jim, throws him over his back, goes ove to the cell and dumps him on his cot and throws blanket over him. Bart then goes to a make-shift cot near desk, he lies down, pulls up blanket and reaches over to put out kerosene lamp,
(v.0.) Good night, Sheriff. Bart smiles and shakes his head and turns out kerosene lamp.
Revised 2/22/73

The office is apparently empty. From behind the drapes we HEAR the muffled voice of Governor William J. Le Petomane singing a few bars of the immortal "Avalon". The door opens, one of the Governor's flunkies ENTERS holding a telegram. He looks around for the Governor; does not see him and is about to EXIT when he HEARS the singing. He tentatively searches the room for the source of the sound. He finally moves in the right direction toward the drapes. He pulls the drape aside revealing the Governor and Miss Stein in an affectionate embrace on a small chaise lounge. The Governor is playing a little ukulele as he sere- nades his secretary.
Err...Governor.
What?...who are you?
Your brother-in-law. I work for you. Urgent telegram, sir.
What's your name?
Harry.

Yeah...that's right...Harry. You say a word about this to my beloved wife, your beloved sister, and I'll have you fired and burned...give me that. He rips the telegram from the man's hand and begins to read it.
(mumbling) Mumble, mumble,mumble.,.ASSHOLE! (CONTINUED)
Anything you say, Bill. She starts to turn over.
NO! Not that...not now! This is inrageous. I must speak to Heddy. (as he EXITS) Serious business...serious business --.serious business.
on the wall over Le Petomane’s desk depicting a bride and groom. CAMERA ZOOMS INTO painting. Groom's face moves from side to side, The groom's face is that of Lamarr's,

(working himself into a euphoric frenzy) The black sheriff scheme is working to perfection, The citizens are enraged. They should be pulling up stakes any moment. The time is right to move into Rock Ridge and snap up the land. (laughs) Today Rock Ridge, tomorrow...Laredo. cUuT TO:

Jim and Bart are seated across the desk from each other. Jim is rolling a cigarette. Bart picks up two pieces of cigarette paper, wets the end of one and carefully glues it to the other. Jim picks up little sack of Bulldurham tobacco, proffers it to Bart.
Need the makin's? BART; No thanks, got my own. Bart takes out his own little sack, reaches into it with two fingers and spreads some of his private stock across the cigarette papers.
Ya know what they're callin' me don't you?
' (sealing his cigarette) What's that?
Deputy Nigger. Jim laughs, strikes a match, lights Bart's cigarette and then lights his own. Bart takes a deep drag.
(in a strained, high, breathy voice) Once I establish myself in this here place, that might turn out to be an important position.
(sniffing the air) Ah, Arizona Gold. Listen, do me a favor. Don't go out there. You can't win these people over, no matter what you do, They are just not going to accept you.
That was yesterday. This is a brand new beautiful day. You don't understand human nature. Once you establish yourself, they've got to accept you. (CONTINUED)
117 (Cont.) Bart rises, snubs out his cigarette and tucks the stub in his shirt pocket and exits.
An ELDERLY WOMAN wearing a bonnet approaches Bart.
(tipping his hat) Mornin', Ma'am. And isn't it a lovely morning.
Suck wind, Nigger.
He closes his eyes and shakes his head. He Looks back to jail to see if Jim noticed the exchange.
at cell window from Bart's P.O.V. He raises his forefinge and mouths "that's one."
continuing his walk up Main Street. He comes upon a group of fighting children. Three boys are beating up on one. Bart moves in to break tp the fight.
Three against one, come on, that’s no way to fight. The kids scatter, leaving their victim sprawled in dust. Bart bends over and notices a toy tin star pinned on the boy*s shirt. (CONTINUED)

Step up ladies, gentlemen and Mongos. Dive for buried treasure. This is the exact spot where the Spanish Armada was sunk by the British Navy leaving millions in Spanish Doubloons on the bottom of the sea.
Spanish Balloons? Mongo take chance. SCREEN FLIPS;
WE SEE Bart place helmet over Mongo's head. Mongo is alre wearing diver's suit.
Where Mongo get air?
From this wonderful antique pump. Bart spins the wheel a couple of times. Dust flies off.
Ohhh. Good. Bart finishes fastening helmet and Mongo climbs down ladd inte well,
Good hunting.
Begins pumping, Mongo under water in well looking around.
He stops pumping. He looks at his pocket watch.
I'm on my break. He folds his arms.  141. 142. 143. 65.

He begins grabbing at his throat. He tugs on hose. A sign comes down next to him which reads: FOR MORE AIR DEPOSIT“25 CENTS Mongo pitifully searches hermetically sealed diver's suit small change. cuUT TO:
WE SEE a huge cannon from which hangs a sign reading:
FROM THE CANNON." To the right of the cannon WE SEE an old-fashioned box camera mounted on a tripod stand. Next the camera holding a flash gun WE SEB Bart, dressed in a beret and blue smock.

Hurry, hurry, hurry. The last time this remarkable photo surprise will be offered in this territory before the new cannon laws go into effect. From o.s., WE HEAR SOUND EFFECTS, SQUISH, SQUISH, SQUISH. Mongo ENTERS THE FRAME, still dressed in his diving suit. He stops in front of the cannon and opens the front of his helmet -- a lot of water comes out.
How much?
Twenty five cents, Only one tenth of a dollar. Mongo searches fruitlessly for money.
(continuing) Don't worry about the tariff, Pal, catch you later.
He climbs up ladder and begins lowering himself into the barrel of the cannon.
Now remember...when the cannon roars...smile. Mongo nods his head and disappears into barrel.
(TO CAMERA)

I'd say Mongo's as smart as a '38 Buick. Bart whistles to someone OUT OF FRAME. We HEAR a loud rumbling noise and into THE FRAME we see wheeled another large capnon. The second cannon is placed in front of the first one and its barrel is lowered until the barrels of both cannons are mouth to mouth.
Ready? From inside first cannon we HEAR Mongo's muffled reply.

Ready. Bart is handed both lanyards, he pulls them simultaneousl There is an incredible ROAR as both cannons go off. The SCREEN IS BLACKENED by smtke. cuT TO: Int. TAGGART'S TENT RAILROAD CAMPSITE CLOSEUP of Lamarr's face. He is deep in thought. CAMERA
Hmn. So he managed to outwit Mongo. It seems we have made a strategic blunder.
(v.0.) How so, Mr, Lamarr, sir? CAMERA PULLS BACK during Lamarr's next speech. (CONTINUED)

145 (Cont.) 67. LAMARR: . We have made one of the most primi- tive tactical errors in military procedure. We have underestimated our opponent, CAMERA comes to a full stop, revealing Lamarr seated in a sudsy bathtub. Seated on a stool next to him is Taggart.
Thought for sure Mongo would mash him into little sheriff meatballs. Can't understand it.
Be still! My mind is a raging torrent flooded with rivulets of thought cascading in a waterfall of creative alternatives,
Gol durnit, Mr. Lamarr, I ain't heard such pretty talk since I seen Charles Boyer as Pepe Le Moko.
Shut up!
Yes sir. (in lower voice, to himself) But he sure talked lovely. For a moment, all is still as Lamarr thinks. Suddenly, Lamarr crashes his fist down into the water, drenching the nearby Taggart.
Of course! That's it!
(brushing his soggy clothing) That's it all right. And it will work!
You bet it will! (raising his hand like a schoolboy) Are you taking questions now, sir? (CONTINUED)
Yes.
What are you talking about? Elementary, cactus-head. The Beast has failed. And when the Beast fails, it is time to call in Beauty.
Beauty?
Don't be impatient, Taggart. All in good time. All in good time. She's never failed me before. Of course: (he Laughs) She'll bring him to his knees... Where's my froggy?
(panicked) I don't know, sir? Ah. I didn't see him when I came in.
Well look, damn your eyes, look! Lamarr searches in the tub frantically. Taggart looks all around the tent.
Oh, here it is, sir, It was under your hat.
Hurry, hurry. Give it to me. Give it to me! Taggart hands Lamarr a large green rubber frog. Lamarr takes it, kisses it and places it in tub. (to himself) That was a close one.
PAE IW: Revised 2/22/73
A poster hangs outside the saloon. It reads:
We SEE a picture of her, wearing a homburg, blue in stripe suit and smoking cigarette in long older.

head_text.subj: NOW BE CHANGED TO LILI VON SHTUPP,

text: A small, cheap, makeshift affair. She sits in front of make-up mirror wearing homburg, blue pin stripe suit. She is putting on finishing touches of her make-up. There is a KNOCK at the door.
Willkommen, Bien Venue, Welcome. cuT TO:
Hedley Lamarr enters, carrying flowers.
For you, my dear,
Oh, how ordinary. (calls OFF CAMERA) Leopold, put zees in vater. (CONTINUED)

Revised 2/22/73 148 (Cont.) We HEAR the dressing room door open. A man who looks strikingly like Eric von Stroheim in "Grand Illusion" ENTERS. He is bald-headed and sports a strange neck brace. He is dressed in a WWI Gérman officer's tunic. He approaches table, lowers wooden arm, places flowers in it, snaps wooden arm back into place, thereby destroying flowers; makes sharp right face and exits. Lamarr stares after him curiously.  70. 148 (Cont.)
Lili, I cannot find the words that truly express my joy at the rekind- ling of our association.
Bullshit. What's ze job?

Why must it always be business with us? He moves closer to her, breathing heavily on her neck. Lili continues making up. (continuing) Why do you constantly put me off? Do you find me so...unattractive?
Only zexually. Lamarr is stung.
(continuing) Now, come on, Lamarr. What's ze job?
I want you to seduce and abandon the sheriff of Rock Ridge...think you can do it?
Is Bismark a herring? There is a loud rapping at the door.
(v.0.) Five minutes.... At the same time his hand smashes through the door and WE SEE wooden arm sticking into the room.
(v.0.; continuing) Sorry. The wooden arm is withdrawn.  149. 150. 71.

Mongo is vertically chained with about 100 yards of heavy steel cable chain to the cell door. He is sleeping like a baby. CAMERA WIDENS to TWO SHOT. Jim is staring at Mongo in amazement. He saunters over to Bart.
Incredible. I still can't believe it.
He was nothing. The bitch was in- venting the Candygram. They'll never give me credit for it. There is a RAPPING at the window. cuUT TO:
Framed in the window we see the same elderly woman that had insulted Bart that very morning, holding a steaming pie in her hands.

(whispering) Sorry about the 'suck wind' this morning. I hope this apple pie will in some small way say thank you for your courage and ingenuity in defeat- ing that horrible Mongo. BART; Thank you ma'am. Much obliged. Good night. Bart closes window. As soon as the window is closed, ther is a RAPPING at the window. Bart opens it.
Of course, you'll have the good taste not to mention that I spoke to you?
Of course.
Well, you've got one on your side. There is another RAPPING at the window. Bart opens it. (CONTINUED)
150 (Cont.) It is Howard Johnson. He is holding a laurel wreath.
Sheriff, I want you to have this wreath. Meant to give it to you on the day you came to town. Bart accepts the wreath.
Thank you. Much obliged. Good night. Closes window. There is another RAPPING. Bart opens window. Howard is still there.
(whispering) Of course, if anybody asks you where you got it, just tell them you stole it out of my store.
Got'cha. Bart closes window. There is another RAPPING. It's the town Barber in his smock, Barber shows Bart scissors and comb.
I want to apologize for not being able to take you today. You come around anytime tomorrow. Give you a haircut and shave on the house. Good night.
Much obliged. Good night. Bart closes window. There is more RAPPING. Bart opens window, Barber is still there.
The best time would be about 4 o'clock in the morning. I know I'll be free then.
Solid. Bart closes window.
(continuing; to Jim) I'm rapidly becoming a big underground success in this town. (CONTINUED)  150 (Cont. 1) 151. 73. Revised 2/22/73
Gee, in another 25 years you may even be able to shake their hands in broad daylight. C'mon, I don't want to be late. That Lili Von Shtupp is opening tonight.

Cowpokes at bar knocking down drinks. The place is chock full of first-nighters fresh in off the trail. There is a general air of happiness and despair per- meating the atmosphere. Suddenly we HEAR drum roll. The place quiets dow as the spotlight hits the stage. COWBOY MASTER OF CEREMONIES steps forward.

And now, ladies and cowboys, the gal you've all been waiting for...the Bay-varian Bombshell herself...let's hear it for Lili Von Shtupp. Saloon patrons give out a big CHEER. Lili enters through curtains. She is dressed in homburg, blue pin stripe suit.

Sank you, ladies and cowboys. And now, I vould like to favor you viz my vorld famous wendition of "I'm Tired"...ze song zat closed Poland. But wight before I do, I'd like to slip into somezing more comfortable... wiz your kind permission.

You're too kind. She walks into wings and returns immediately, clad in an incredibly sexy outfit, The place goes wild. Lili signals for quiet. A hush falls over saloon. Softly, she begins to sing. (CONTINUED)
151 (Cont.)

head_text.subj: I'VE HAD MY FILL OF LOVE

text: Suddenly drum starts new “up tempo". Lili reaches down and snaps off her whip, cracks it and goes into release of song as she marches down into audience.
(continuing)
Lili approaches Gabby Johnson, who stares at her and giggles and is simultaneously mumbling, "Ravvid, ravvid, ravvid...
(continuing)

head_text.subj: ALL AT ONCE WITH A START

text: A big ugly cowhand reaches for her breast. Without missing a beat, she knees him in the groin. He quietly faints.
(continuing)

head_text.subj: BUT YOU SAY WHAT THE HELL
LIFE IS SHORT, LOVE IS SWELL

text: Lili approaches a table at which Bart and Jim are seated and slips Bart an envelope.
(continuing)
(CONTINUED)

Jim is at the desk. Bart enters and closes the door, lean against it and sighs. He wears his crushed hat.

(taking the writ and studying it) Hedley Lamarr. Why would a dude like Hedley Lamarr care about Mongo? Well, it's legal. Bart takes a bucket of water and walks to where Mongo is trussed in chains and splashes it in Mongo's face.
Orange juice, toast and coffee...and a paper. Mongo yawns and stretches, easily breaking out of the cha

Approaching campsite. Their horses kicking up clouds of dust.  158. 159. 160. 81.

and runs

Black, white, yellow and Armenian working side by side, spanning America with rails of steel to bring all of us together in a symphony of brotherhood. A large orchestra begins to play. Holy mother of pearl. That's the niggra that hit me with the shovel. What the hell do you think you're doing with that tin star, "boy''?
Watch that "boy" shit, red neck. You're talking to the sheriff of Rock Ridge.

Well, don't that beat all. Here we take the good time and trouble to slaughter every Indian in the West and for what? So's they can appoint a sheriff that's darker than the Indians, to wit, a niggra. Well, I'm depressed. Taggart slumps down in his saddle.
(timidly) Excuse me, Mr. Taggart, sir. Hate to see you Like this. What if me and the boys shot the nigger dead. Would that pep you up?

Don't pay no mind to that alky. He can't even hold a gun, let alone shoot it. On the count of three. One..two... three. There is fusillade of gun fire.
The guns scattered on the ground. They are all in the same pose; grasping their hands in pain.
His arms are still folded across his chest. Little curls of smoke slowly rise from guns in his holsters.
(as one) Whooee!!
He pulls out gun and holds it on Taggart and his men. BART: . Don't just stand around stunned, grasping your hands in pain. Let's have a little applause for the Waco Kid.

In terror. Hand comes INTO FRAME and slaps her viciously across the cheek. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal Lamarr as slapper and Taggart as a delighted spectator. Standing against the wall, bound and gagged, is Leopold. On the wall next to him, also tied securely, is his arm.

I want you to round up every vicious criminal and gun slinger in the West. I want: rustlers cut-throats murderers (CONTINUED)

168- (Cont.) 169 170. LAMARR: (Cont.) bounty hunters desperados pugs mugs thugs half-wits nitwits dimwits con men Indian Agents Mexican bandits vipers snipers muggers buggerers bank robbers train robbers horse thieves horn swaggelers bush whackers ass kickers shit kickers and Methodists.

on horse.

reining up.

Goodbye. Bart claps his hand over his mouth and leaves.

(v.0.) Well, speaking for mineself, I'm com- pletely in the dark. (CONTINUED)  98. Revised 2/22/73 196 (Cont.) BART; I'm hip. Now, before the sun comes up we are going to build on this site an exact copy of the town of Rock Ridge. Every building, every store front, every rock and every tree right down to the orange roof on Howard Johnson's outhouse. And when Hedley Lamarr and his men come riding in tomorrow they're gonna attack the wrong place at the wrong time and we'll be waiting. Townspeople ad lib,

Wrong and there's why. We HEAR a clanking of wagon wheels, and INTO FRAME, Charlie and Jim come riding out of the dark followed by buckboards filled with railroad workers and con- struction materials.

Railroad workers who have agreed to help us make our dream come true and all they want in return is a little land they can call their own to home- stead. What do you say? There is a lot of grumbling and mumbling.
who speaks for the townsfolk.

- 4w, prairie shit...everybody.

But they'll be here in half an hour.
Right. We've got to work fast. You men start working on the dummies and you men come with me. I've got an idea that will slow 'em down to a crawl.

Men, you are about to embark on a great erusade to stamp out runaway decency in the West. leading horde across the prairie. They suddenly come upon the toll booth. They rein their horses to a screeching halt, SOUND of tires screeching on pavement.
